definition:
[**Theorem**]{} Suppose $X$ is a connected space and $x$ is a point in
$X$. If $X\setminus \{x\}$ is a disconnected set in $X$, then $x$ is a
[**cut-point**]{} of $X$ [@jameson; @ward].

### Examples

1.  Any point of ${\mathbb{R}}$ with the usual topology is a cut-point.

2.  If $X$ is a normed vector space with $\dim X>1$, then $X$ has no
    cut-points [@jameson].

[9]{} G.J. Jameson, *Topology and Normed Spaces*, Chapman and Hall,
1974. L.E. Ward, *Topology, An Outline for a First Course*, Marcel
Dekker, Inc., 1972.
